description.narrative: Management Plan
Management Budget for Instutionnel Activities

Approche intégrée de la planification et de la gestion de l’occupation des sols pour renforcer et d’asseoir la conservation de la biodiversité dans l'éco-région de forêt dense et humide de l’ouest du Bassin du Congo

title.narrative: PIMS 1583 Full BD: Cons of Tra

description.narrative: Conservation of Trans-boundary Biodiversity
capital of a political entity
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To maintain the ecological functions and connectivity of TRIDOM and ensure long-term conservation of its protected area system through integrated, sustainable and participatory management in the interzone between the protected areas

[1a] 1. Population of key species selected as indicators of improved protection from threats in TRIDOM
1a) elephant and great ape
MTR (2012) comments:
Unrealistic indicator: establishing a baseline and inventory populations represent a job and a very high cost of such a zone. Existing data are limited and require an update.
Even performing sampling, the cost is very important, and measuring a change would be very difficult to statistically validate.

comment.narrative:
Baseline for elephant and great ape populations to be defined after YR 1 & 2 of project implementation
[2013 note: Baseline not yet established]

By mid-term:
Elephant and great ape populations are stabilized or have increased in TRIDOM compared to levels at YR 1
By EOP:
Elephant and great ape populations are stabilized or have increased in TRIDOM compared to levels at Year 1.
[2013 note: Not possible to establish targets, because baseline was not established.]
[RTA note: Target in PIR corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

During the interface between two inventories Great Mammals, This indicator is filled through the probability of observing elephants and gorillas in clearings blocks in community supervision. But following the end of the operational phase of the project which was completed at the end of December 2014 and the non-appropriation of the practice by the State Parties, the data was only collected between July and December 2014. Thus, 14/17 CBM blocks in clearings were recolonized in the dry season with an oscillating observation probability from 0.125 to 0.16% against 0.10 to 0.125% last year on a sequence of 02 visits by the clearing day. The ideal would be to achieve a rate of 0.25% for tour operators offer a "Bottom Line" a Community eco-tourist destination. Also breeding groups and large individuals continued to be observed in clearings of blocks in the forests and Messok -Dja Djoua-Ivindo in the Congo. Besides the recognition of cross-border network migration paths of elephants between protected areas of the three countries indicated very good connections between Congo and Gabon, connections relatively well between Congo and Cameroon and between Cameroon and Gabon via the North -West Congo and lack a connection between Gabon and Cameroon.

description.narrative:
[1b] 1. Population of key species selected as indicators of improved protection from threats in TRIDOM
1b) Nile crocodiles, slender snout crocodiles, giant turtles and Congo clawless otters
MTR (2012) comments:
Impossible to measure captures without having guards present at all times. In terms of management agreements, WWF implements some activities. However, it is difficult to measure indicators, but what is done is still in the direction of providing data on trends. To specifically inform the indicator, even in small areas, there should be regular surveys to measure the trend, but the cost would be very high.

comment.narrative:
Baseline for populations of Nile crocodiles, slender snout crocodiles, giant turtles and Congo clawless otters to be defined after YR 1 of project implementation
[2013 note: Baseline not yet established]

By mid-term:
A collaborative management agreement is under negotiation for each of the pilot river segments to assure community involvement in protection of aquatic resources.
By EOP:
In at least two pilot river sites per country, populations of Nile crocodiles, slender snout crocodiles, giant turtles and Congo clawless otters are stabilized or have increased.
[2013 note: Not possible to establish targets, because baseline was not established.]
[RTA note: Target in PIR corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

Following the operational closure of the Project, the implementation of last year's follow-up protocol was only continued during the period from July-December 2014. However, the trends identified did not have difference with those of the previous fiscal year.

description.narrative:
[2] 2. Percentage of TRIDOM free of hunting
MTR (2012) comments:
It is impossible to measure this indicator. Hunting happens all over the TRIDOM area, including in national parks, and especially around the villages.
Hunting itself is not a problem, as long as it is not done on a large scale for sale on the domestic and international markets, and it is not poaching (ie hunting in the national parks, excluding the opening periods, and do not respect the protected species and quotas enforced by law).

comment.narrative:
Baseline for level of hunting to be defined after YR 1 of project implementation
[2013 note: The baseline not yet established, though there are many studies. ]

By mid-term:
The percentage of surface area without bush meat hunting is stabilized or has increased compared to levels at Year 1 in 50% of TRIDOM through an effective law enforcement system and collaborative management schemes with the private sector and communities
By EOP:
The overall percentage of TRIDOM without bush meat hunting has increased compared to levels at Year 1 through an effective law enforcement system and collaborative management schemes with the private sector and communities
Ancillary meta-indicator (proposed by MTR in Jun 2012):
The average distance covered on foot by village hunters is stabilized or has decreased compared to levels at Year 1.
[RTA note: Target in PIR corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

The implementation of simple Management Plans (under the management of 17 pilot village lands - hot-spot for poaching) for poverty reduction and anti-poaching, and maintaining or restoring the network migration of large mammals track, continued only during July to December 2014. It is noted that the expansion of the hot-spots could not be reached as planned because of the ineffective mobilization of the private sector. This initiative of Participatory Management Approach has met with very positive response not only of the State Parties, but also local beneficiaries. Community supervision blocks clearings allowed recolonization of 14/17 block large mammals and should in future be reinforced by a cover of 30/30 days into two teams of 15/30 days. The second wave of development support Revenues Generating Activities (IGA) compatible with the conservation of biodiversity, with integration of non-timber forest products processing machinery (NTFPs) could not be reached for lack of financial availability. Thus, Poacher’s Conversion Plan has not been effective as there were no permanent occupation for anti-poachers. The average effort of hunting in the village land has not seen a significant difference compared to last year. In short, this uncertain ownership by the beneficiaries is due to the short duration of experimentation (1.5 / 7 years). As a result, the establishment of a Transitional Strategy is necessary prior to the new phase of project development so as to avoid the risk of losing this important achievement.

description.narrative: [3] 3. Funding levels

comment.narrative:
Baseline will be established in YR 1 (through analysis of costs and funding sources)
As per PRODOC ($ million in 2007):
1) Project PA budgets in TRIDOM $2.629
2) Project non-PA budgets in TRIDOM $0.094
3) Government PA budgets in TRIDOM $2.157
4) Government non-PA budgets in TRIDOM $0.901
TOTAL (1 through 4): $5.781
Sub-total (1 and 3) $4.786
(in a different calculation, baseline finance for the duration of the project was assessed at $9.2 million, or $1.3 million p.a. this is a more credible figure)
This covers < 10% of the core management costs in the TRIDOM

Not possible to inform the indicator with precision.
However, we report the following:
It is already planned recruitment in the next second half of 2013, a consultant to conduct a study on the compilation of existing recurrent costs of monitoring, sources of funding, GAP and potential local sources of finacing to mobilize sustainable income from payments for environmental services. Moreover, a working group has been set up during the same semester discuss proposals for a draft taxation on wildlife vision tourism and wildlife hunting tourism submit to the Government of the Congo, the development this of activity in the Odzala-Kokoua and Park and its periphery.

The document on the determination of the recurrent costs for the ongoing monitoring of biodiversity for cross-border activities is still pending approval by State Parties. Therefore, this activity should be within the framework of the new project phase which is under development.

description.narrative:
[1-2] Outcome 1. The land-use and the governance structures of a trans-border complex for biodiversity conservation and sustainable natural resource use are designed, endorsed and operational.
Output 2. A transboundary status is adopted for the TRIDOM and operational management systems are effective at the regional, national and local levels.

[4] 1.1 Land-use plan with legal endorsement
[4a] Regional
MTR (2012) comments:
The target for 4 years, as per PRODOC, should be the EOP target (more realistic).

comment.narrative:
Land use plan and governance structure nonexistent; only 9 protected areas gazetted
[RTA note: baseline corrected in the PIR to be in conformity with PRODOC.]

By mid-term: The Governments have adopted the legal instruments adopting the land use plan and they cover at least 80% of the 40,000 sq km interzone and are published in the national press.
Mid-term enabling conditions:
(i) Complementary data collection is continued (satellite images, field checks, etc.).
(ii) For each country updated thematic land use maps for the interzone and / or existing protected areas are produced to serve as a basis for discussion.
(ii) Land use scenarios ensuring that key connectivity areas receive conservation attention are proposed.
(iii) Multi-level stakeholder consultation is conducted on proposed land use scenarios.
By EOP:
All implementation measures (e.g. gazettement decrees) of the land use plans are adopted and enforced.
[Note on logframe revision: MTR recommendation adopted. Targets are adjusted down. Mid-term enabling conditions are also included now. RTA endorses the revision of the target. ]

The States Parties (during the Tri-National Committee for Supervision and Arbitration (CTSA) grouping representatives of the Governments of the three States Parties) approved through a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) consensual plan for integrating migration corridors of large mammals in National Plans for Land Use. This innovative and efficient tool includes five (5) chapters and twenty-seven (27) articles. The first chapter deals with general provisions such as the demarcation of the migration corridors of large mammals selected for national and cross-border plans. The second chapter deals with the management measures bunk compatible and incompatible uses in the consensual plan of integration corridors. The third chapter discusses the contribution to the maintenance and/ or restoration of migration corridors in conjunction with dealers and others involved in TRIDOM. The fourth chapter deals with the implementation and monitoring and evaluation of the MOU at country and sub-regional levels. The last chapter deals with the various and final provisions, including the commitment of countries in the process of obtaining the status of transboundary biosphere reserve of UNESCO.

description.narrative: [5] 2.1 Official international status for TRIDOM complex

comment.narrative: Consensus reached on proposed transboundary status of TRIDOM.

By EOP: The Governments have adopted the legal instruments adopting the land use plan and they cover at least 80% of the 40,000 sq km interzone and are published in the national press.
By Mid-term enabling conditions:
(i) Complementary data collection is continued (satellite images, field checks, etc.).
(ii) For each country updated thematic land use maps for the interzone and / or existing protected areas are produced to serve as a basis for discussion.
(ii) Land use scenarios ensuring that key connectivity areas receive conservation attention are proposed.
(iii) Multi-level stakeholder consultation is conducted on proposed land use scenarios.
[Note on logframe revision: MTR recommendation adopted. Targets are adjusted down. A mid-term target, (in the form of enabling conditions) is also included now. RTA endorses the revision of the target.]

As part of the approval of Consensual Plan of Integration Corridors in National Plans, in Jun 2015, the Government of Gabon has been designated to lead the process of obtaining for TRIDOM landscape, status of Transboundary Biosphere Reserve MAB / UNESCO.

description.narrative: [5a] baseline studies to support the international status for the TRIDOM complex carried out

comment.narrative: No studies carried out
All the necessary studies have been carried out and validated in preparation for the submission.
Kindly see the previous indicator as this has already been explained.

description.narrative: [6] 2.2 Master plan\'s official endorsement

comment.narrative:
TRIDOM masterplan is designed and implemented in at least 20% of the project area.
By Mid-term enabling conditions (abbreviated from PRODOC):
(i) Pre-conditions:
a. An inventory of trans-boundary status and management models is conducted.
b. The results and recommendations of the inventory are discussed with all key stakeholders.
c. An action plan leading to adoption of an official status and trans-boundary management systems is adopted.
(ii) By mid-term:
a. A consensus is reached on proposed trans-boundary status of TRIDOM.
b. The tri-national agreement on TRIDOM status signed.
c. The main orientations of the TRIDOM master plan (operational rules, management structures, model collaborative management agreements, including with indigenous people, and zoning) are outlined.
d. The TRIDOM management structures are outlined.
e. The participatory process to draft / update protected area management plans is pursued in some areas.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC. Mid-term enabling conditions now included.]

Progress made towards the target, but not yet achieved, only the pre-conditions for achieving the mid-term target have been more or less fulfilled.
These are: (i-a) progress towards official status; (i-b) some inventories exist; (i-c) a blueprint for a concerted management system is emerging, but consensus is not yet achieved.
MTR confirmed status for this indicator (Jun 2012) is:
It is first necessary to prepare national plans segment TRIDOM prior to the merger in a tri-national Master Plan. Participatory preparation of a draft will not be possible before 2014 a priori.
The project reports the following:
Following a review of the key impacts of the project at the last Steering Committee in February 2013 indicators, it will now be developed with the participation of all governments and stakeholders active and / or potential involved or interested in developing activities in the core and cross bands landscape TRIDOM a consensual proposal occupancy and sustainable land use management with particular areas of high conservation value (ZHVC), assets and potential corridors.
Kindly see Indicator 1.1: Land-use Plan with legal endorsement

description.narrative: [7] 2.3 Score in management effectiveness

comment.narrative:
Tracking tool for management effectiveness applied at the baseline for 7 PAs.
2007 Scores available for:
1) Minkebe National Park (Gabon): 46/92 = 50%
2) Mwagne National Park (Gabon): 39/92 = 42%
3) Ivindo National Park (Gabon): 56/92 = 61%
4) Odzala Kokoua National Park, (Congo Rep); 49/92 = 51% (score corrected after verification of calculations)
5) Nki National Park (Cameroon): 58/92 = 60% (score corrected after verification of calculations)
6) Boumba Bek National Park (Cameroon): 62/92 = 67% (score corrected after verification of calculations)
7) Reserve de Faune du Dja, (Cameroon): 50/92 = 54% (score corrected after verification of calculations)

All existing protected areas in TRIDOM under effective management
Mid-term target established in 2013 as all scores above 60%.
EOP Target established in 2013 as all scores above 70%.
[Note: RTA endorses the revision of the target.]

As part of the PAMETT assessment for the end of the National Parks Project TRIDOM segment gave the following results:
Score for Congo:
1) Odzala Kokoua National Park: 79/102 = 77.45%, an increase of 12% over the mid-term evaluation;
2) Lossi Gorilla Sanctuary: 35/102 = 34, 31% (baseline assessment)
3) Ntokou-Pikounda National Park: 19/102 = 18.62% (baseline assessment)
NB: The evaluation of protected areas segments for TRIDOM Cameroon and Gabon was carried out in July 2015 and the results will be completed as soon as possible.

n/a refer to indicator above
The National Park Management Plans for Odzala- Kokoua and Lossi Gorilla Sanctuary were approved by the Government in the second quarter of 2014.

description.narrative: n/a refer to indicator above

comment.narrative: n/a refer to indicator above
n/a refer to indicator above

National Plans on land in Cameroon and Gabon are still undergoing the approval process. Furthermore, the development and approval of the MoU on the consensual plan for integrating large mammal migration corridors (TRIDOM landscape) in the national pre-shots land use in Cameroon and Gabon were much appreciated by both governments.

description.narrative:
[2-5]
Outcome 2. The capacity to monitor trends in biodiversity, resource exploitation and ecological functions and to minimize pressures on natural resources is strengthened in TRIDOM.
Output 5. Mechanisms are in place to strengthen effective biodiversity conservation in logging concessions.

[8] 3.1 \"State of the TRIDOM\" ecological monitoring and control reports
[RTA note: indicator amended for clarity and conformity with PRODOC]

comment.narrative:
Some basic information is available on TRIDOM from the CARPE (report) and the et \\\\\\\"Etat des forÃªts\\\\\\\" report
[RTA note: baseline reconstructed based on correction inputted by the MTR]

By mid-term:
TRIDOM annual monitoring reports completed and findings used to inform decision-making.
By EOP:
Final annual â€œState of the TRIDOMâ€?, including recommendations for the future, is published.
Midid-term enabling conditions:
(i) The management agencies and partners in the interzone and existing protected areas adopt a monitoring strategy and a work plan defining roles and responsibilities on data collection and analysis.
(ii) From Year 2 onwards, monitoring data are included in a TRIDOM GIS database in close cooperation with GIS database systems used in existing protected areas and national GIS database systems.
(iii) At least one partnership is concluded with a national or an international entity (such as the foreseen Ipassa ecological research station, Global Forest Watch, etc.) to develop joint monitoring and training activities.
(iv) At least 20 conservation and forest professionals in each country are trained in monitoring (data collection protocol and analysis).
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC. Mid-term enabling conditions now included.]

Consolidation and structuring of a biodiversity monitoring system by setting up a GIS database based in line ministries, fed through a space-time “Anti-Poaching, Ecological and socio-economic” monitoring device, to facilitate decision making at various levels of management.
This tool has the ability to communicate on 30Km bands on each side of the borders, the location and trends:- The correlation between poaching hot-spots, areas of concentration of large mammals and location of crossing points of large mammals and poachers at the borders of countries;- The likelihood of quantitative and qualitative observation of elephants and gorillas in and around the 17 blocks (drive) favorite clearings, setting community supervision;- Simple phenology of species most palatable plants around the blocks clearings and continuous monitoring;- The cartographic recognition and determination of the network and the degree of use of migration corridors of large mammal;- The observation of aquatic fauna in segments of streams of high Ivindo and Middle Dja.- The cross-analysis of the observations of the Great Mammals trends in protected areas and key corridors of the central core of TRIDOM.

description.narrative: [9] Number of staff trained in ecological management

comment.narrative: Basic knowledge [by few staff]

By mid-term:
At least 20 professionals in forest conservation in each country trained in ecological monitoring (60 in total)
By EOP:
The monitoring of biodiversity, ecological functions and resource use is performed by teams (professional and populations).
The training on Ecological Monitoring was not carried out as planned.

description.narrative:
[10] 4.1 Endorsement of operational procedures for monitoring
[RTA Note: This indicator was previously misplaced. Its formulation is improve to indicated that it relates most to monitoring, rather than enforcement though the former supports the latter with vital information.]

comment.narrative: MIKE (Monitoring of Illegal Killing of Elephant) project only effective in MinkÃ©bÃ© National Park; need for monitoring strategy for the entire TRIDOM landscape

Interim monitoring strategy implemented in entire TRIDOM.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]
Kindly refer 3.1

description.narrative:
[LEGACY INDICADOR 10]
Note: This indicator was misplaced; it has now been moved immediately above to 2-3]
4.1 Endorsement of operational procedures for monitoring
[MTR (2012) comments:]
MIKE has been replaced by MIST, but it is not directly related to law enforcement.
For the purposes of the law itself, some actions have been taken as the establishment of monitoring committees of litigation (including two in Gabon).
[RTA Note: Indicator was misplaced and it is now moved to Outcome 2, Output 3, immediately above.]

comment.narrative:
[LEGACY BASELINE FOR INDICADOR 10]
MIKE (Monitoring of Illegal Killing of Elephant) project only effective in MinkÃ©bÃ© National Park; need for monitoring strategy for the entire TRIDOM landscape

[LEGACY TARGET FOR INDICADOR 10]
Interim monitoring strategy implemented in entire TRIDOM.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

The bi-national border patrols officially launched since July 2013, continued in the second half of 2014 and were particularly disrupted by a major operation called "Top of the INTERPOL Ivindo" in November 2014, triggering the process of calling upon sponsors and the reconstitution of cross-border links in the chain of poaching.
Thus in the functioning of the judiciary committee of the three States Parties for the monitoring of cross-border litigation on wildlife, cross-border operations Judicial proceedings following the successive arrest by binational patrols Minkébé National Park in Gabon, of four shipments of elephant poachers from Cameroon and Congo, denounced their sponsors during the investigation, who were immediately placed under arrest through the cross-border cooperation of the judiciary involved in the INTERPOL. On the basis of numerous other arrests, authors, accomplices and co-authors of elephant poaching were also arrested.
To this end sentences are being issued and several criminal networks are being undone at local and international level.
Furthermore the traditional chains of prosecution were considered the weak links as previously only members of indigenous and village communities were the subject of criminal prosecution while sponsors had little to worry about.

description.narrative:
[11] 4.2 Signed collaborative management agreements or otherwise adopted regulation
[11a] on co-management
[11b] on enforcement
[RTA Note: indicator folded out into 2 sub-indicator to correct previous reporting confusion.]

comment.narrative:
[11a] Only one collaborative management agreement currently exists between gold miners and MinkÃ©bÃ© National Park
[11b] No collaboration on enforcement
MIKE (Monitoring of Illegal Killing of Elephant) project only effective in MinkÃ©bÃ© National Park; need for a surveillance strategy for the entire TRIDOM landscape (baseline reconstructed)

[11a] From year 3 onwards (i.e. by mid-term) and each year at least one collaborative management agreement is signed by resource users in every country of TRIDOM; four (4) other agreements are adopted with pilot communities for hunting and trade in bushmeat.
This would entail a total of at least 9 agreements, ~3 per country, plus 4 other agreements with communities.
By EOP, at least 6 co-management agreements including two for protection of river fauna and 4 village hunting agreements signed in each country.
[11b] By mid-term, the three governments adopt a cross-border protocol for the fight against poaching. By EOP, a law enforcement system at the tri-national level and as part of Master Plan is operational in the interzone and in existing protected areas
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC and re-formulated for clarity and upon suggestion from MTR.]
In Congo, conservation series Yengo-Mohali, Ndzéhi and Messok-Dja located in forest concessions have been managed by the community.

description.narrative: [12] 4.3 Number of requests for replication of collaborative management agreements

comment.narrative: No requests documented
In each country at least four requests exist for replication of co-management agreements including two for river management i.e. approx. 12 requests in all by EOP.
Kindly see the previous indicator as this has already been explained.

description.narrative:
[13] 5.1 Best practices adopted regarding control of hunting in logging concessions
[13a] Enforcement

comment.narrative:
[13a] The Bordamur model, between the MinkÃ©bÃ© project and Bordamur logging company regarding control of hunting.
[RTA note: Baseline information complemented upon suggestion from MTR.]

By EOP,in at least 50% of the logging concession in the interzone best practices are adopted and integrated in their internal regulations.
Mid-term enabling condition:
In each country, negotiations are concluded with a private investor to build and operate model ecotourism facilities in the pilot sites and partnerships on ecotourism management in protected areas are established in at least Odzala-Kokoua National Park.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC. Mid-term enabling conditions now also included.]

The general non-binding agreements have been negotiated with Forestry, Mining and agribusiness through the development of Consensual Plan of Integration of Migration Corridors of large mammals in national plans of land use. This helps in strengthening the existing business rules in the exploitation of mining concessions and similarly help in: Identifying areas of high conservation value, migration corridors of large mammals and development of artisanal gold mining sites;- Support the development of income generating activities (IGA) in the vicinity of village lands;- Support in CBM blocks of nearby keys clearings or for the maintenance and restoration of large mammal migration corridors;- Support to the anti-poaching fight through USLAB;- Insert the offshore operating model with catering;- Introduce canine brigades in anti-poaching on major roads laid;- Respecting the principle of maximum sustainable yield, and (further processing of natural resources);- Respect international standards adapted to each specific extraction.

description.narrative: [13b] Policy and regulation

comment.narrative: [13b] Policy on wildlife conservation in logging concessions not yet available at national level

By mid-term, in at least one country a policy is adopted at national level on wildlife conservation in logging concessions.
By EOP, in all three countries a policy is adopted at national level on wildlife conservation in logging concessions.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]
Kindly see the previous indicator as this has already been explained.

description.narrative:
[14] 5.2 Percentage of infractions related to hunting in logging concessions
MTR (2012) comments:
It is very difficult to measure the crimes that take place in forest concessions. No baseline has been developed.

comment.narrative:
In logging concessions representing at least 50% of the surface area under logging in the interzone infractions related to hunting have decreased by 75%.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

By mid term, in logging concessions representing at least 50% of the surface area under logging in the interzone infractions related to hunting have decreased by 75%.
By EOP, in logging concessions representing 80% of the total surface area under logging in TRIDOM, infractions related to hunting (e.g. transport of bush meat in vehicles) have decreased by 75% in concessions having critical hunting rates at the project outset and remains at or under baseline level in concessions already implementing an effective control system at project outset.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]
Kindly refer paragraph 2.2 on poaching hot-spots.

description.narrative:
[3-6]
Outcome 3. Benefits from community-based natural resource management contribute to poverty alleviation.
Output 6. Viable community initiatives providing socio-economic incentives for biodiversity conservation are designed and operational.

[15] 6.1 Number of local jobs in ecotourism enterprises
MTR (2012) comments:
The eco-tourism development requires a clear identification of potential and partnerships with the private sector (developers) to make the necessary investments and promoting the offer.

comment.narrative: Baseline to be defined after YR 1 of project implementation [RTA Note: It was not established]

By mid-term, in each pilot site at least 15 community members have stable direct employment as a result of ecotourism development.
By EOP, in each pilot site at least 25 community members have stable direct employment as a result of ecotourism development.
The number of days spent by tourists in the TRIDOM increased by at least 15% per year since Year 4.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

Commissioning the Odzala Kokoua National Park by Congo Conservation Company (Tour Operator) has contributed for the creation of additional 15% increase in job opportunities for the local communities compared to the previous year.

description.narrative:
[16] Community benefit sharing
[RTA Note: now folded out into two sub-indicators, as per suggestion from MTR]
[16a] A legal framework for community hunting
[16b] 6.2 Village income in areas targeted by the project
MTR (2012) comments: Unrealistic goal: considering the size of TRIDOM, 20% or 50% is really crowded.

comment.narrative:
[16a] Community hunting is regulated in the existing legislation
[16b] Baseline to be defined in YR 1 during socio-economic assessment

[16a] By mid-term, a pragmatic legal framework for community forest / wildlife management (including community hunting) was adopted in each of the tree countries.
By EOP, in each country segment of the interzone at least five community-based forest and/or wildlife management zones are providing steady legal revenues to local actors as a result of the project efforts
[16b] No targets established.

In the Odzala National Park in Congo -Kokoua (the fund of villagers after 5% growth in turnover of ecotourism revenues) the Congo Conservation Society is rapidly growing in proportion with the increase in the number of tourists related capacity-range means of childcare. It is worth noting that tax regulations, to enable a fair distribution of these benefits for the development of all village land, is not yet established. Also the National Park will need to recruit a powerful development expert to assist local communities who is capable of designing projects that are in line with conservation of biodiversity.

description.narrative:
[17] 6.3 Number of requests for community hunting zones or forest management zones
MTR (2012) comments: Impossible to measure indicator. The catchment population is about 100,000 people. No baseline achieved (or achievable: a priori everyone hunting in the region).

comment.narrative: Baseline to be defined after YR 1 & 2 of project implementation

By mid-term, in each country segment of TRIDOM at least 25% of communities are requesting establishment of a community forest and / or hunting zone.
By EOP, in each country segment of TRIDOM at least 50% of communities are requesting establishment of a community forest and / or hunting zone.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC]

After supporting the facilitation of the valorization of Odzala National Park in Congo-Kokoua, the following issues have become a challenge:
- Decrease in the number of tourists that visit the Park
- Impact of limitation on the local population;
The possible Resolution:
- Trigger future community tourism blocks clearings surveillance in the interzone and community hunting tourism.
During fiscal year 2014-2015, the objective was to deepen the implementation process of hunting areas identified last year and research valuation opportunities. But the reluctance of operators to invest because of a possible slow return on investment.
To work around this major difficulty, we strongly hope that the new phase TRIDOM Project development can grant:
- Support the establishment of Eco-Lodge in village land management pilots;
- Acquisition in accordance with CITES export quotas parrots community to collect in glades in community supervision in Tala-Tala FMU Ngombe and Congo.

description.narrative: [18] 6.4 Number of people who abandoned illegal hunting

comment.narrative: Baseline will be defined during YR 1, through socio-economic assessment

By EOP, income generated from ecotourism development and community-based forest and wildlife management in the areas targeted by the project have induced local populations to stop unsustainable natural resources harvesting.
Mid-term enabling conditions (abridged from PRODOC):
(a) In each country, the process leading to one additional community forest or community hunting zone is initiated in the interzone and around protected areas.
(b) A microfinance facility and training in business planning and financing targeting community-based biodiversity enterprises is implemented in each country.
(c) In each country, one additional community forest or community hunting zone is established.
(d) A draft program to set up a microfinance facility and training in business planning and financing targeting community-
based biodiversity enterprises is designed and discussed in each country.
(e) In each country segment, as a result of the project efforts, at least five community-based forest and / or wildlife management are providing steady legal revenues to local actors as a result of the project efforts.
[RTA note: Target corrected to be in conformity with PRODOC. Mid-term enabling conditions now added.]

description.narrative:
[4-7]
Outcome 4. Sustainable funding is mobilized for the conservation and sustainable management of the TRIDOM.
Output 7. A multi-level financing plan is developed, endorsed and implemented.

[19] 7.1 Percentage of management and protection costs covered by long-term financial resources
MTR (2012) comments: Achieving this objective in a project seven years seems very difficult.

comment.narrative:
As per PRODOC ($ million in 2007) a total of $1.3 p.a. is likely available for the purpose.
This covers < 30% of the core management costs in the TRIDOM
The Financial Scorecard has not yet been applied.
[RTA note: Baseline reconstructed.]
Long-term financial resources are available to cover 20% of the core management costs in TRIDOM (in particular law enforcement and protected area management) by mid-term and 50% by EOP.
Kindly refer Point 3.3 on Funding

title.narrative: Sustainable Management of the Mbe River Forested

description.narrative: Sustainable Management of the Mbe River Forested Watershed through the Development of a Payments for Ecosystem Services (PES)
Gestion durable des éco-systèmes de la rivière Mbé pour le paiement des services environnementaux
capital of a political entity
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Design a sustainable financing mechanism for long-term protection of the MbÃ© River forested watershed, while strengthening the legal, policy and institutional framework necessary to ensure its adoption and successful implementation
A collaborative framework proposed and initiated

comment.narrative: None
Collaboration between key institutions involved in PES exists by EOP

A consultant was recruited for a study of the legal framewalk and policies. The study will make recommendations on ecosystem services in the various laws governing land use and propose legal obligations for water users to contribute to watershed management.
The study will ensure that payments and compensations are possible, and define who has the right to buy and sell ecosystem services.
